DOC.HEAD: Judge Approves Bunker Hunt Bankruptcy Protection Plan
Eds: SUBS 7th graf to CORRECT amount to be paid to IRS to 80 percent, sted 70 percent.
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge has approved a reorganization plan for ex-billionaire Nelson Bunker Hunt, paving the way for him to emerge from bankruptcy protection next month. Under the plan approved Friday by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Harold Abramson, the $222 million left of Hunt's multibillion-dollar fortune will be transferred to a trust next month and proceeds from the trust will be used to repay debts. The plan was jointly proposed by Hunt and a group of his major creditors. Hunt's bankruptcy attorney, Russell Munsch, said his client was ``very glad to be out of bankruptcy, but bitter at what bankruptcy has cost.'' In September 1988, Hunt and his wife, Caroline _ who owed more than $1 billion to creditors _ filed for protection under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law. The smaller estate of his brother, William Herbert Hunt, still remains under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, but is expected to be closed next week. William Hunt's plan faces challenge from two creditors who have about $25 million in claims. About 80 percent of the money raised under the liquidation of Bunker Hunt's trust is to be used to repay the Internal Revenue Service. Minpeco S.A., a Peruvian mining concern that won a $132 million court judgment against the brothers stemming from their alleged attempt in 1979-80 to corner the silver market, will also receive a large share of the liquidated estates. Under terms of the settlement, Hunt lost his real estate holdings, including the largest cattle ranch in Australia and the Bronco Bowl recreation center in Dallas. He will be allowed to keep his $1.8 million Dallas mansion, his Cadillac, household furnishings, clothing and 50 percent of the proceeds from non-producing gas and oil properties.
